segments.text: I guess start briefly describe your background.
With what I have in your letter, I guess you could just restate part of that again.
From a police standpoint?
Just your background.
You can give me any education you've had.
Born in 23, graduated from high school in 41.
Started at TCU on a general...
degree, dropped out, started to go to North Texas Agricultural College, University of Texas at Arlington, and dropped out of there.
Went to the jewelry trade and wound up being a watchmaker for 17 years.
In 59, joined the Fort Worth Waste Department.
to basically two years walking the beat, two years in youth division, two years in detective office and the burglary division, made sergeant
One year in communications for dispatch office, then went to patrol division.
Oh, it was several years there, 10, 11, 12.
I'm not sure right now which.
Then went to records division, wound up as supervisor of the identification office for the remaining seven or eight years before retirement.
OK.
When you joined the police force in 59, what was your training like?
What was stressed?
The training, at that time, the training wound up, it was an eight-week school, 40 hours a week.
They were trying to get across the law, which involved a number of classroom errors, naturally.
The department procedures or policies.
First aid was stressed heavily.
I don't think of anything else right now.
Driving wasn't stressed.
It is now.
Knowledge of the town, streets, buildings, names, this type of thing.
But I believe that covers most of it.
What's the training like today?
How do they compare it?
There's almost no comparison.
Now they have a 16-week course.
Before they're hired, they're given more testing, interviews, psychological evaluations, stress situations.
than you can imagine, and most of them are useless.
But the actual training division now, or training school, as the rookies go through, involves quite a bit of time at the firing range, getting familiar with pistols,
and shotguns.
Most of that brought on the Supreme Court decision requiring or holding departments liable in a vehicle police shooting where the man might not have been adequately trained in some court's opinion.
They're given quite a bit of driver's training in emergency pursuit driving.

this type of stuff basically for the same reason and because the frequency of accidents involve quite a bit of money in repair work and downtime for a vehicle should be in use first aid I don't believe they're giving any first aid at all now they boast us heavy with it laws
They're stressed.
Department policies are stressed.
Your civil rights or actions that subject the city to lawsuit are stressed heavy.
Physical training is stressed quite a bit.
They've got a gym and they...
have a physical P.E.
class like in high school every day.
But there's not a whole lot of comparison with what it was five years ago.
Why do you think it changed?
A lot of it is departments or the city's desire for trying to

provide better educated more educated a more rounded educated officer a lot of it is because the laws have been interpreted in such a way that subjects the city to civil liability so much so I believe

One of our attorneys a while back was telling me at that particular time we had 25 or 27 separate lawsuits pending in federal court on civil rights violations, which in the late 50s and early 60s were never heard of.
And it's subject to quite a bit of financial stress.
Other reasons would be protest groups hollering, minority groups stressing employment in their particular minority.
There would be a variety of other reasons.
More of a, I mean, as far as the city was concerned, like there's a protection of their own.
Protection of their own.
Okay.
You said one of your first assignments was to the foot patrol in the downtown area.
How do you think the public perceived the police then?
That particular job at that time was described
to me, and I believe they were pretty close to right.
It was basically 75% public relations.
The officers assigned to that detail would stand on a major downtown intersection directing traffic.
The job was to direct traffic 30 minutes, then walk to B, which would be, oh,
four, six, or eight block area, getting familiar with the business people, professional people, and getting to know the neighborhood and being seen.
It was more of a high visibility job than anything else.
There were some police actions that you took that just happened to come back.
I believe it was all the probability was 75% public relations.
We thought we did a good job.
People that were around us enjoyed having us to talk to.
But that particular job has been abolished now in favor of putting more policemen in patrol cars.
How do you think that, well,
It's kind of hard to follow up on that one, but how do you think police are viewed today, since there's really not that same job anymore?
As a department?
As an entity, how does the public see the police department?
Now, let me break it down a little bit.
How do I feel about it?
How does the government feel about it?
How does our department feel about it?
How do you think?
the public sees the police department today?
The general public has a reasonable amount of respect to the Congress and the police department.
I'm talking about four.
That's all I want to know.
They will support them to
a reasonable degree.
Other towns are more and other towns are less.
I believe Fort Worth would be more or less in the average on that.
Okay.
To give you an example, a number of years ago,
This is one back in 2015, 25 years.
There were studies made and so forth from police departments and its inadequacies and needs.
And everybody that was involved in the study recommended that we have a new police building.
At that time, the police department's main offices were in the basement of the city hall.
The city council at that time thought that was a great idea and immediately put it to a bond vote to build a new city hall.
They dropped all suggestions and the police building was completed and put it out to the city hall.
The bond vote
when the new city hall issue was rejected by the public.
Several years later, another survey was made, and the prime recommendation of that study was that we have a new police building, a centralized police building.
The council, which had changed
thought that was a great idea, and immediately put it out to a bond vote for a new city hall.
Dropped all suggestions to the police building, but they won the city hall, because then the police would use an old building if they wanted to go up.
When they released a bond vote by the people, it was rejected.
This makes twice that the same issue has come up and been rejected.
The third time,
would be maybe 10, 12 years ago.
And the thing come up just exactly like it had before.
The public finally voted for a new city hall after the recommendation had been made with the new police building.
And the police wound up getting two-thirds of the old city hall.
Is this public confidence or public respect or your city officials who are actual employers of the police department?
This has finally changed within the last year.
Boat was finally brought up again and they did build a new police building in connection with the county jail and within the last year have moved into a new police building.
Twenty years later.
If at any time you do this you feel like throwing in something from a previous question you thought of or just anything, feel free.
You said the Fort Worth police chief usually has risen up from within the department's own ranks.
And then in 1777 they brought Brown over from Dallas.
What effect did it have when you bring in an outsider to be the police chief?
on the operation of the force and the attitudes of the officers?
The effect, as far as A.J.
Brown was concerned, Brown was a career man that was a Dallas police officer.
He got his 20 years in and Dallas has a 20-year retirement plan.
Then he could retire and get a job somewhere else.
Then when he reached retirement age, he started on a Dallas retirement, which meant that he had to have a job.
He wound up as a police chief in Norfolk, Virginia.
Then Fort Worth hired him from Norfolk to come to Fort Worth.
But he's basically a Dallas trained, Dallas oriented police officer.
He was
Nearly all of his career was assigned to inside jobs and worked very few investigative or police enforcement jobs on the street.
And when the Fort Worth got him, a number of the officers were, I believe, more or less naturally resentful
The city council didn't seem to feel that our department had a man capable of being chief.
I believe we did and still do.
The council more or less explained it in an unpublicized way

there had been certain cliques developed within the police department that they wanted to bring in on the outside, break up those cliques, and then within three to five years, have a chief on the inside back.
This held true in that Brown was here three years.
He brought in several radical ideas,
radical to full worth idiot.
He finally left more or less at a time of considerable dissension within the city.
And the city officials
promoted a man to chief that had been in the running for several years, in contention for several years.
He was chief for five or six years and has just now officially retired and went back outside and hired a man from Los Angeles to be their next chief.
In the late 60s and early 70s, it seemed like civil rights finally reached Fort Worth as an issue.
It began to make news and be more dominant.
What's the police response to when you have such a major shift in relations between races?
Now, are you talking about your protest minority groups?

Just the civil rights, not so much the protesting, but the shifting relations between, you know, your traditional relations between blacks and whites or any minority were changing, and how did that affect the police, or how did the police respond, or was it a factor at all?
I'm not sure I just understand just exactly what you're asking me.
The way blacks and whites and anybody got along for decades and decades was changing.
How did that affect?
How did the police respond to this?
Did it change anything?
Yes, it changed a whole lot.
All of your... Well, it started out as blacks.
Then it evolved.
Hispanics, and next come the flower children.
And since then, there's been half a dozen splinter groups of minorities making complaints or protests or demonstrations of some form.
But it did make a big change in the police department.
And that not just the police department, the city, the city officials, the courts, the training division for the recruits, the employees they hired.
It made quite a bit of difference to us.
How would you describe the difference?
Okay, it changed things, but how would you describe that change?
Well, one of the first examples to bring up, used to we had niggers and negroes.
The first minority groups or blacks or
whatever they want to be called, decided they wanted to be called Negroes, as to correspond or rhyme with your neat, Negroes.
Don't call them niggers, call them Negroes.
The next group come along said, we don't want to be called Negroes, we're Negroes as a race, we are a color, we are colored people.
It wasn't a year later until they decided, well, we are colored, but we're black.
Now we want to be called black people.
We had a session there, or not a session, but a series of sensitivity sessions.
That's a joke if there ever was.
But in bringing those up, we had a supposed to have been a highly respected professor from the college.
And in the classroom discussion, we asked him, what would you call them?
They don't even want to, they don't know what they want to be called in himself.
He said, well, if I was talking to somebody one-on-one,

In the first sentence, I would address him as a colored person, as a Negro person, and as a black person, and see which one he responded to best, and then that's the way I would address him from then on.
I got a lot of hit people.
The sensitivity sessions were to take, you had a militant blacks and a group of policemen,

that was supposed to be representative of the police department, and sit them in one room, the policemen were to be quiet, sit still, and not let themselves get upset, and the blacks were to call them every name under the sun that they could think of for eight hours.
And yet, if they made one word of complaint, they received a disciplinary letter in their personnel file.
That was to go on for a week at a time.
Naturally, there was some hard beatings over those.
That's what happened.
That's hard to believe, that part.
It's fact.
How long did that continue?
I mean, the sensitivity?
Different groups under different names with different lengths of time in attendance.
Approximately two years.
Assuming there was no... Oh, this was the thing to do.
Everybody was doing this.
This was to educate the policeman as to how the blacks felt when he was called a black or a colored person or a negro or a nigger or a motherfucker.
That's...
So we'd know how they felt.
This may seem a silly question, but you...
There was no gain as far as the police were concerned from this?
It seemed like it just generated hard feelings.
I believe hard feelings only did generate.
We had a number of the policemen come back that had been sent to one of those schools and say, I'm not going back or I'm going to quit.
You can do what you want to with the chief, but I ain't going back to another one of those places.
There was never anybody fired for not going.
When civil rights first became an issue in Fort Worth, were there any blacks in the force at that time?
Yeah.
What were their opinions?
Did they ever make a public stance?
No.
NAACP wouldn't allow that.
What did they do?
How did they respond?
At that time, we didn't have anywhere near the proportion of blacks.

on the department there must have been say 12 or 15 this is when we had a department of 300 personnel uh mostly they were assigned to black communities because that's where they knew the people and the people knew them everyone that ever got fired or had
personnel problems the issue was over females every black policeman we had that was killed was killed by his wife up until oh probably 65 68 somewhere along that because he wasn't in the business
Since then, we've had more police, more blacks, more females, more Hispanics, now Asiatics, and so forth hired.
And other issues have come into it, but that's kind of the background of what it was.
As the number of blacks on the force increased, the proportion increased,
How did that change the relationship between blacks and whites on the floors?
It seemed like it was a...
Some good, some bad.
We've been forced through threats, threats of a quota system,
threats from the city manager, threats from the council regarding personnel or pay raises.
One thing or another, more emphasis being placed on recruitment of minorities.
Federal grants get involved.
When money's involved, things get serious.
Some of the minorities that we hire are good.
A lot of them are hired for, to fill a quota, or if there is no quota, to make it look close to one.
A lot of the blacks that we have hired aren't worth a damn and they're being carried on the table just because they're black.
You can't fire them as easily as you can a wife.
Females that we've hired
Less than 50% of them are effective police officers.
The other 50% are hired to, not hired, but they are placed in jobs that any clerk can handle.
But they're a police officer and going to a police officer's salary.
And they're incapable of being a police officer.
And I believe that
That percentage would even be higher among the black females.
Hispanics, I don't know about them, but I don't know many of them.
Let's see.
One time before, not recently, but a while back, we were talking, and you mentioned that the NAACP wouldn't pursue any litigation that involved a black officer.
They limit themselves to only action about the white police.
What's a policeman to think when something like that happens?
Only limit our action to just this.
